questions.text: Which is NOT true about fatty acid diarrhea in contrast to bile acid diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Responds to cholestyramine Primary bile acid diarrhea: Chronic secretory diarrhea resulting from increased bile acid spillage into the colon. Bile acid sequestrants (like cholestyramine) effectively reduce diarrhea by binding bile acids to prevent spillage into the colon. Fatty acid diarrhea (Steatorrhea): Passage of large, bulky, and malodorous stools with increased stool fat excretion to > 7% of dietary fat. Reduced recycling of bile acids by the enterohepatic circulation (Ileal diseases or ileal resection) Increased entry into and concentration of bile acids in the colon. Malabsorption due to inadequate bile acid concentrations in the small-bowel lumen. No role of bile acid sequestrants here.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, D: True

Extraedge:

In functional diarrhea or irritable bowel syndrome, reduced FGF19 secretion by ileal enterocytes lead to increased hepatic bile acid synthesis. And this excess bile acid spills into the colon. Resection or disease involving < 100 cm of ileum results in bile acid spillage into the colon. Resection > 100 cm results in bile acid loss that exceeds liver synthetic capacity, and malabsorption causes diarrhea due to bile acid deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following malabsorption has defects in the absorptive phase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Celiac disease There are three phases of enteral nutrient processing – Digestive phase (Luminal digestion): Initiated by lingual and gastric lipase and gastric pepsin and continues in the small bowel by the actions of pancreatic enzymes and bile salts. Absorptive phase ( Small intestinal mucosal digestion and absorption): Mediated by enterocyte brush border enzymes, including disaccharidases, enterokinase, and peptidases. Post-absorptive phase (post mucosal absorption): The nutrients are reprocessed in the enterocytes to enter lymphatics or the bloodstream.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Defect in digestive phase: Reduction in pancreatic enzyme secretion Option: C. Defect in post-absorptive phase: Re-esterified triglyceride cannot exit the epithelial cell because of the f ailure to produce chylomicrons. Option: D. Defect in post-absorptive phase: Damage to lymphatic channels leading to malabsorption and diarrhea.

Extraedge:

Celiac disease may have lactase deficiency and crypt hyperplasia, and fluid hypersecretion. Associated autoimmune disorders: Type 1 diabetes mellitus Autoimmune thyroid disease Dermatitis herpetiformi The Marsh classification categorizes different types of celiac disease PHASE, PROCESS PATHOPHYSIOLOGIC DEFECT DISEASE EXAMPLE Digestive Lipolysis formation Micelle formation Decreased lipase secretion Decreased intraduodenal bile acids Chronic pancreatitis See Table 318-1 Absorptive Mucosal uptake and re-esterification Mucosal dysfunction Celiac disease Postabsorptive Chylomicron formation Delivery from intestine Absent β-lipoproteins Abnormal lymphatics Abetalipoproteinemia Intestinal lymphangiectasia

questions.text: Which of the following is the Gold standard for establishing the presence of steatorrhea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Quantitative stool fat determination Steatorrhea: Passage of large, bulky, and malodorous stools with increased stool fat excretion to > 7% of dietary fat . A 72-h collection for weight/volume (Quantitative) and fecal fat determination is the gold standard for documenting the presence of steatorrhea, or fatty stool.

Extraedge:

No role of bile acid sequestrants Patients with chronic pancreatitis present with steatorrhea. Patients with steatorrhea develop a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins A, E, D, and K.

questions.text: A patient with celiac disease is advised to be on a Gluten free diet. Which of the following can be consumed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Millet Celiac disease (celiac sprue) (gluten-sensitive enteropathy) The mnemonic for food with gluten is BROW …… barley, rye, oats, and wheat. Millet doesn’t contain gluten. Immune response to gluten ingestion. Autoantibodies to tissue Gluten is found in foods produced from wheat, rye, barley , and some varieties of oats . Tissue transglutaminase is involved in the pathogenesis of this disorder.

Extraedge:

HLADQ2 and DQ8 are found in 25–35% of the general population. A negative test of these alleles is beneficial for ruling out celiac disease.

questions.text: The intestinal biopsy finding is shown below. The findings are suggestive of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Celiac disease Biopsies of Celiac disease typically show characteristics: Villus blunting Crypt hyperplasia and inflammation Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. Cuboidal appearance and nuclei that are no longer oriented basally in surface epithelial cells.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Normal intestinal mucosa Option: B. Lymphangiectasia: Dilated lymphatics in the submucosa, lamina propria, and clubbed villi . Option: D. Intestinal lymphoma: Malignant lymphoma cells in the lamina propria and submucosa.

Extraedge:

Tropical sprue biopsy findings are similar to celiac disease. Whipple’s disease: PAS-positive macrophages in lamina propria.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of persistent symptoms in a patient who fulfills all the criteria for the diagnosis of celiac disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continued intake of gluten The mainstay of celiac disease treatment is a strict gluten-free diet . A most common cause of residual disease activity is dietary non-adherence or inadvertent gluten exposure For persistent symptoms , a biopsy is required: To determine the degree of disease activity To rule out refractory celiac disease or T-cell lymphoma.

Extraedge:

Resolution of symptoms: Biopsy follow-up to document complete healing of villous atrophy. Serologic follow-up to confirm compliance with a gluten-free diet. Refractory celiac disease Type 1 - normal intraepithelial lymphocytes Type 2 - clonal expansion of CD3+ intraepithelial lymphocytes Type 2 – Worst prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following Pathogenetic mechanisms explains diarrhea in Celiac disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Bile-acid malabsorption resulting in bile-acid-induced fluid secretion in the colon

options.label: B
options.text: Endogenous fluid secretion resulting from crypt hyperplasia

options.label: C
options.text: Secondary lactase deficiency, a consequence of changes in jejunal brush border enzymatic function

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Patients with celiac disease have villus atrophy in the proximal small intestine and may present in any way of the following: Mucosal malabsorption – Steatorrhea Lactase deficiency – Osmotic and Secretory diarrhea Crypt hyperplasia and fluid hypersecretion – Secretory diarrhea Reduced recycling and increased bile acid entry into the colon – Secretory diarrhea

Extraedge:

Biopsies show characteristic villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation The Marsh classification categorizes different types of celiac disease–related lesions and quantifies the severity of disease involvement.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Whipple's disease EXCEPT?

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine

options.label: D
options.text: Weight loss, diarrhea, and Cardiac problems

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute multisystemic disease Whipple’s disease is Chronic Multi-organ disease Causative agent: Tropheryma whipplei whipplei is a gram-positive, non-acid-fast, PAS-positive rod . Classic symptoms: Arthralgia, Weight loss, Diarrhea, and abdominal pain . CNS and cardiac involvement are common and occur later in the disease. PAS-positive macrophages also characterize the intestinal lesion.

Extraedge:

Most commonly occurs in middle-aged men. Joint disease is present in >80% of patients whipplei can be detected by PCR on involved tissue It is difficult to detect it in the bloodstream

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the causative agent of Whipple's disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High infectivity Tropheryma whipplei is a Gram-positive Non-acid-fast Periodic acid-Schiff ( PAS) -positive bacillus With a characteristic tri lamellar / trilaminar plasma membrane surrounded by a cell wall. Highly infective The high burden of bacilli is due to underlying host immune deficiency and possible secondary immune downregulation induced by the bacterium.

Highyeild:

A low CD4/CD8 ratio characterizes intestinal and peripheral T-cells. The optimal regimen is still being determined. For patients with chronic Whipple's disease (either classic or localized chronic infection) An initial phase of an intravenous antibiotic that is active against T.whipplei and is known to penetrate the blood-brain barrier Followed by 12 months of oral maintenance therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic sign in patients of Whipple's disease who experience relapse after the induction of remission with antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dementia Clinical failure is suggested by: Positive PCR in the relevant specimen from patients who fail to respond clinically to adequate therapy, Or have a recurrence of symptoms after initial improvement Relapse reflects incomplete eradication of the organism with initial therapy. Relapse often manifests with evidence of CNS infection or involvement The CNS is the most common site for relapse The rationale for prolonged therapy is to permit complete eradication of the organism, thereby reducing the likelihood of relapse. Adequate CNS activity may be critical to preventing relapse.

Extraedge:

Many patients with suspected relapse may have had IRIS (immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome. If a CNS relapse occurs after a lower dose of ceftriaxone, a higher dose (2 g IV twice daily) may be more effective.

questions.text: The steatorrhea in the patients of Whipple's disease is generally believed to be secondary to:

options.label: C
options.text: Increased number of PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria of the small intestine

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of above Whipple’s disease with gastrointestinal disease progression shows: Villous atrophy, Lymphangiectasia, Crypt hyperplasia, and Apoptosis of surface epithelial cells Resultant diarrhea is due to Damage to the mucosa with impaired absorption/malabsorption Increased leak of water and solutes

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, C. All lead to steatorrhea.

Extraedge:

Involvement of lymphatic or hepatic tissue may manifest as noncaseating granulomas that can mimic sarcoid or granulomatous vasculitis

questions.text: Which of the following finding is most suggestive of Active Whipple's disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of the T. whipplei bacillus but the presence of PAS-positive macrophage

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of the T. whipplei bacillus inside of PAS-positive macrophage

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of the T. whipplei bacillus outside of PAS-positive macrophage

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of the T. whipplei bacillus but the absence of PAS-positive macrophage

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of the T. whipplei bacillus outside of PAS-positive macrophage
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presence of the T. whipplei bacillus outside of PAS-positive macrophage Infiltration of infected tissue/lamina propria by large numbers of foamy macrophages containing periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)– staining inclusions (representing ingested bacteria ) is a characteristic and most common PAS-positive inclusions are resistant to diastase . The presence of the T. whipplei bacillus outside of macrophages is an indicator of active disease.

Highyeild:

Post-bulbar duodenal biopsies should be performed. Diagnostic yield is greater for tissue specimens than for body fluids whipplei has been successfully cultured from Blood, CSF, Synovial fluid, BAL fluid, Valve tissue, Duodenal tissue, Skeletal muscle, Lymph nodes, Culture is not practical since it takes months to obtain a positive result

questions.text: Which of the following is appropriate for the treatment of Whipple's disease ?

options.label: A
options.text: Meropenem for 12 weeks followed by oral TMP-SMX for one year

options.label: B
options.text: Meropenem for six months followed by oral TMP-SMX for one year

options.label: C
options.text: Ceftriaxone for two weeks followed by oral TMP-SMX for one year

options.label: D
options.text: Meropenem for 12 weeks followed by oral TMP-SMX for lifelong

questions.correct_answer: C. Ceftriaxone for two weeks followed by oral TMP-SMX for one year
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ceftriaxone for two weeks followed by oral TMP-SMX for one year Treatment of classic Whipple’s disease: Ceftriaxone (2 g IV q24h) for two weeks or Or Meropenem (1 g IV q8h) for two weeksEither of the above followed by oral TMP-SMX (160/800 mg) twice a day for 1 year . Asymptomatic/symptomatic CNS disease Ceftriaxone (2 g q12h) for 2 – 4 weeks Or Meropenem (2 g q8h) for 2–4 weeks Either of above followed by oral doxycycline or minocycline plus hydroxychloroquine Treatment of endocarditis Oral doxycycline plus hydroxychloroquine for ≥18 months or Ceftriaxone (2 g q24h IV) 2 to 4 weeks or Penicillin (2 million units q4h IV) plus streptomycin (1 g q24h IV) for 2–4 weeks Either of above followed by oral TMP-SMX (800 mg q12h) for 1-year

questions.text: Which of the following antibody test is most sensitive and most specific to diagnose Coeliac disease ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti tissue transglutaminase antibodies Screening for celiac disease is done by testing for serum antibodies: Tissue transglutaminase IgA Antiendomysial Deamidated antigliadin antibodies.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . IgA anti-endomysial antibodies are found in 90% coeliac patients. They are a very specific & sensitive marker for coeliac disease and dermatitis herpetiformis. Option: C. Anti-gliadin antibodies can be found in the serum of patients with overt and subclinical coeliac disease and in some controls. Option: D. Reticulin is a term for collagen-containing connective tissues in many organs. Anti-reticulin antibodies may be detected occasionally as part of the autoantibody screen. They are in themselves of no significance. However, in around 50% of cases, they may provide evidence of unsuspected coeliac disease.

Extraedge:

Deamidated antigliadin IgG antibodies or tissue transglutaminase IgG antibodies are detectable and diagnostic in IgA-deficient patients. The diagnosis in adults with positive antibody levels should be confirmed by endoscopy with small-intestinal biopsy

questions.text: The most common CNS manifestation of Whipple's disease is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dementia CNS disease is defined by PCR-based detection of whipplei in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Develops in ~50% of patients The most common are cognitive changes, including Memory impairment with progression to dementia Personality and mood alterations Hypothalamic involvement (e.g., polyuria/polydipsia, sleep-cycle disorders) Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia

Extraedge:

Commonly affected areas of the brain: Median temporal lobe Midbrain Hypothalamus Thalamus A low CSF glucose level has been reported
